newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai dissident due for release June 4 - mother.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai dissident due for release June 4 - mother.

text.p: Prominent Shanghai dissident Bao Ge, jailed three years ago, is due to be released on June 4 after having been refused visits from relatives for 18 months, Bao's mother said on Thursday.
Bao, sentenced to three years "re-education through labour" in 1994, was a member of the Shanghai-based Association for Human Rights.

He was involved in a number of activities, including a campaign to get Japan to provide compensation for atrocities committed during its occupation of China from 1931 to 1945, his mother, Wang Yufen, contacted by telephone, said.
"I have received a letter from him saying he expects to be released on June 4," Wang said. "He says June 4 is going to be an important day."
June 4 is the anniversary of the army crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing in 1989, but Bao's mother said there was no connection between that day and his release.
She said she was worried that Bao, 33, would protest to the authorities that his three-year incarceration was illegal that he would get into further trouble.
"As his mother, I'm of course very happy he's getting out, but I'm worried about the political side of things," she said. "They will be watching him."
She said she had not seen her son for 18 months.
"The last time they gave me permission to visit was in November 1995," she said.
Shanghai's small band of dissidents, active in the late 1980s and early 1990s, have either left China or been jailed on various charges.
